text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we don’t combine Zytiga and the radium together. I specifically say that because there have been patients who have had leftover pills and yeah. Hey, the things going up after I try the pill. But actually, when they combined it people did worse so that study has already been done and people got more bone fractures so that’s no fun. So, I just tell everybody, you know, you’ve had it before. You can go on it after but not at the same time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s actually an absolute no-go black box. Okay, good. Family Member: What does the PSA going up, what does it, is it gonna cause it to spread? Doctor: It might really. No. But it might, again it’s not a reflection of what’s happening. It’s almost like oh, the ship’s sinking and the rats are all kind of jumping off. I’ve had patients that go from twenty to one hundred to five hundred and you’re like, oh, but they actually feel better. So, like it doesn’t match you. Family Member: It’s not the biggest thing because people always ask you what’s your PSA. Doctor: Yeah, no, just say oh, I’m on a treatment where the PSA actually goes up and like, you know, we have a vaccine therapy that that happens but Xofigo for sure and we know that because actually one of the fellows who is now faculty wrote a paper on our collective experience when we first started doing it and Patient: Alright. I have something to run by you Doctor: Um hmm. Patient: with me going out of town and taking this. Would I be alright to travel? Doctor: Yeah. So, the good news is that we figured out that you will leave with a piece of paper after the radiation doctor gives you the injection because you will set off the TSA sensors.

text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Sometimes longer than that. Family Member: Okay. Patient: At which point we’ll be transitioning to a different kind of treatment, hopefully. Doctor: Right. Family Member: Okay, so then you’re looking at like, like combinations of drugs? Doctor: Yeah. Normally, we would keep you on the hormone -- forever at that point, unfortunately. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And then, add things to them. Standardly, we would add another hormone, so you’d be on two. text: Patient: Okay, um. Is there any detriment to having the chemo before the radiation? Doctor: So we actually prefer it because we actually know how to treat your whole body systemically with all these medicines from the chemist. (whistle noise) Patient: Right. Doctor: With these medicines, but we also, and it also gives you more time to heal. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: From the surgery, which is better for you as far as long-term side effects. Family Member: Uh hum. Okay. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So we do it in this order for everybody. Patient: Okay. Is the castration, the two years, I understand that is standard care. Are there ever any times when that is shortened or – I understand in my case that is likely two years – I accept that that’s what it’s going to be. Doctor: Okay, okay. Family Member: Is that even in case number three, though, the aggressive with the chemo and the super hormone, or is the hormone; I just want to ask In standard care two you said the hormone shot would be for two years. In the third option with the chemo, how long is that going to be last? Doctor: So the way we’re doing it, it’s still two years.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
